title-group.article-title: COINTEGRATION, ERROR CORRECTION AND TESTS OF PURCHASING POWER PARITY DOCTRINE: EVIDENCE FROM BANGLADESH

abstract.p: Purchasing Power Parity is one of the important issues in International Finance that draws considerable attention by the researchers. There exists mixed evidence on this issue; some studies find supportive evidence on PPP where other rejects it. There exists a bunch of empirical work, which tests PPP regarding the developed countries. However, studies in the context of developing countries are scanty but not non-existent. The authors, in this paper, test PPP in the context of a developing country, Bangladesh, who has witnessed financial liberalization for a decade. Augmented Dickey-Fuller test and Phillip-Perron test are used to test the hypothesis whether exchange rates and prices follow a random walk. These tests show that the data are non-stationary at levels and their first differences are stationary. The authors find supportive evidence of purchasing power parity between Bangladesh and all other four countries considered, by utilizing cointegration techniques due to Johansen (1988) and Johansen and Juselius (1990). An error correction model is estimated to address the short-run dynamics of exchange rate and price ratios of the countries involved. In this regard, variance decompositions analysis and impulse response functions are utilized to further investigate the postulated relationship of exchange rates and prices. This analysis confirms that currency depreciation is inflationary in the context of Bangladesh. Finally, some implications are drawn from the empirical analysis.
